Data.MeaningHint: If you can get to ten thousand different pieces, then that means your sword is absolutely perfect. If your sword dulls before you get to ten thousand, you have to throw it away.
Data.ReadingHint: Carefully draw your manga onto these ten thousand leaf pieces. Maybe you even use your sword again to give them some textured details. You're so creative and talented!
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Now that you have <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> pieces of tiny leaf paper, you decide to turn them into a <reading>man</reading>ga (まん)! Each little leaf piece will become a panel.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: You cut the <radical>leaf</radical> with your <radical>sword</radical> into <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> pieces!

Data.MeaningHint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
Data.ReadingHint: Go outside right now and do something to save the condors. If you don't do something right now there won't be enough time left!
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Right <kanji>now</kanji> the <reading>con</reading>dors (こん) are in danger! Not next week, not next year, right now! Haven't you heard that deforestation and pollution are killing all of the condors?!
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>now</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>now</kanji> as well.

Data.MeaningHint: And, you have no idea how to get them out. They're <kanji>inside</kanji> for good, and it's freaking you out. As in, there's a little person in there, running around, controlling your brain. People think you're crazy, but you know better... He's <kanji>inside</kanji> there, doing evil things.
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine him holding the knife out, threatening to stab your brain. You’re in a conundrum here. If you don’t take him out, you’re in trouble, but if you do try to take him out, he might stab you in the brain with his knife. Try to think a way around this situation, focusing mainly on his knife.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: You know this kanji means <kanji>inside</kanji>, so you can keep thinking about the person that's inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a <reading>kni</reading>fe (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: Your <radical>head</radical> has a <radical>person</radical> <kanji>inside</kanji> it!

Data.MeaningHint: Picture the fins falling onto the sword, and being divided into many parts. And if those fins represented hours, they’d be divided into minutes. Makes sense, right?
Data.ReadingHint: This is how you feed your people: neatly divided, delicious buns. Picture these delicious buns divided into perfectly shaped parts. Yummy.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Now that the fins have been cut into neat <kanji>part</kanji>s, it's time to cut something else: <reading>bun</reading>s (ぶん).
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>fins</radical> that fell onto my <radical>sword</radical> were sliced into many <kanji>part</kanji>s. Following this logic, this also means <kanji>minute</kanji>, which is part of an hour, and <kanji>divide</kanji>, which is the action of splitting something into many parts.

Data.MeaningHint: Take these seven swords and swing them around. <kanji>Cut</kanji> everything in your path, including yourself. Then, think about how dumb it was to try to use seven swords at once, and then feel the pain of the cut you gave yourself. Ouch, ouch ouch.
Data.ReadingHint: Just make sure you think about how you need to give them away in <reading>sets</reading>, and not anything else. This is the most important thing to think about in your head as you're trying to establish the mnemonic for your kanji reading memory. It's gotta be sets.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You <kanji>cut</kanji> them into pairs, and give <reading>sets</reading> (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: If you have <radical>seven</radical> <radical>swords</radical>, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to <kanji>cut</kanji> something.

Data.MeaningHint: Picture all the kids out sliding on the slide at noon during their lunch break. It's hot and dry and they're very happy.
Data.ReadingHint: Watch in horror as Godzilla's giant foot crushes all the kids and their slide at exactly noon. You'd better go...
Data.ReadingMnemonic: <kanji>Noon</kanji> also happens to be the time <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) decided to attack for the same reasons: it's dry and kids are using the slide.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> at <kanji>noon</kanji>. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide.

Data.MeaningHint: Imagine that narwhal sitting there. It waves its flipper and says "hi friend" to you.
Data.ReadingHint: Your narwhal friend goes on to warn you about all those youths, and how they will try to take away your friendship with their good looks and young ages.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: "Hi <kanji>friend</kanji>," says the narwhal. "I must warn you about all the <reading>you</reading>ths." (ゆう)
Data.MeaningMnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> is your <kanji>friend</kanji>.

Data.MeaningHint: We've fattened you up with lots of juicy radical knowledge, so this one should be pretty easy.
Data.ReadingHint: Picture this fat person curled up all cozy-like on their Japanese futon. They look so content! Have you ever slept on a proper Japanese futon, by the way? We're talking premium, cloud-grade comfort — luxurious enough to make you feel like a real fat cat.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Imagine a <kanji>fat</kanji> person who loves to sleep on <reading>futo</reading>n (ふと).
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The kanji is the same as the radical, so this means <kanji>fat</kanji>.

Data.MeaningHint: Imagine a small slide (how could you not, after you see the radicals?). So few people can use this thing, really, but there are a few little ones who can fit on it at least.
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine this in your head. Even the few people who fit on the slide are struggling to get past the Shogun. Meanwhile the Japanese secret service is trying to make sure no one gets close to the shogun while he slides. A few people are crying. They want to slide, they want to leave… It's chaos.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Another reason so <kanji>few</kanji> people can use it is that the <reading>Sho</reading>gun (しょう) is trying to go down the slide. We're talking a grown man who's way too big for this little slide, so a few people have to wait behind him — it's a slide traffic jam.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: You have a <radical>small</radical> <radical>slide</radical>. The thing about small slides is that <kanji>few</kanji> people can use them. Not everyone can fit their bum in a small slide — only a few small ones can make it down.

Data.MeaningHint: Imagine taking a stick and pulling it back into your bow. Imagine how hard you have to pull. This thing is really strong!
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine using all your strength to pull on this bow. Imagine the heat rising in your body. There's sweat dripping down your face. It's so hot, but you have to keep pulling!
Data.ReadingMnemonic: When you <kanji>pull</kanji> the bow back, your body strains and you feel an immense <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) rise inside of you. You keep pulling and the heat grows hotter and hotter.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: If you have a <radical>bow</radical> and a <radical>stick</radical> you need to <kanji>pull</kanji> the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything.

Data.MeaningHint: Also, make sure you know the radicals by heart, it'll help you to learn more effectively, just like with this kanji.
Data.ReadingHint: This is when I start kicking you in the shin and you imagine feeling the pain of getting kicked there. As I kick you in the shin, the stress is getting too much for your poor heart inside your shin. Poor shin, and poor heart.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji>, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your <kanji>heart</kanji> is stored in your <reading>shin</reading> (しん).
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The radical <radical>heart</radical> and the kanji <kanji>heart</kanji> are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!

Data.MeaningHint: Time to open the door to the reading part of this mnemonic.
Data.ReadingHint: Feel the pain of your toe going away. Think about the other side of the <kanji>door</kanji>, where your <reading>toe</reading> is probably rolling around after it blasted off your foot.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: You open the <kanji>door</kanji> and immediately get it closed back on your <reading>toe</reading> (と), literally causing your toe to explode.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>door</kanji> are the same!

Data.MeaningHint: The only direction you need to go in is forward, it's always the right way.
Data.ReadingHint: Close your eyes and picture your home in your mind. Can you tell which direction it is from where you are?
Data.ReadingMnemonic: What <kanji>direction</kanji> do you always know? Which direction do you always want to go? <reading>Ho</reading>me (ほう). Something about your home always stays with you, no matter how far away you go. So if you're lost and you don't know which direction to go, just think of home!
Data.MeaningMnemonic:
The radical and the kanji for <kanji>direction</kanji> are the same! Huzzah!

There is also another meaning too, though. This can also mean <kanji>way</kanji> as well. Think of it this way: When you move in one direction in your life, you are developing your own way. "The way of [your name here]."

Data.MeaningHint: To distinguish this from the "noon" kanji (午), try thinking of the bit poking out of the top of this kanji as a tuft of hair on the cow's head — a cow lick, if you like.
Data.ReadingHint: I hope you know what わぎゅう beef is, otherwise this will be a difficult one to learn.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Have you ever heard of わ<reading>ぎゅう</reading> (wagyu) beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>cow</kanji> are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.

Data.MeaningHint: No, I am not your father... but this kanji / radical set is!
Data.ReadingHint: Hopefully you know who they are. If not, think about your father laughing like this: ちちちちちちちち〜！
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Imagine your father is <reading>Cheech</reading> (ちち) from Cheech and Chong.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>father</kanji> are the same.

Data.MeaningHint: Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.
Data.ReadingHint: Smell the <kanji>fur</kanji> as you <reading>mow</reading> it down. Feel it flying everywhere. It's giant, so it must be pretty intense. Make it more intense to help yourself to remember the reading of this kanji better.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: With <kanji>fur</kanji>, whisk your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it's fur). You're surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel and smell like? Now it's time to get rid of it. There's just too much <kanji>hair</kanji>! To get rid of it, you'll need to <reading>mow</reading> (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they're loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think "fur → in the fur → get rid of the fur → mow the fur," in that order. That'll get you to "mow," which will help you to remember the on’yomi.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: <kanji>Fur</kanji> and <radical>fur</radical> are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean <kanji>hair</kanji>, too, though more like furry hair.

Data.MeaningHint: Know your radicals, yo!
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine the fluffy wool of the sheep, stopping you from moving forward. You can't push past it, no matter how hard you try.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: You have to <kanji>stop</kanji> because there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>stop</radical> radical is the same as the <kanji>stop</kanji> kanji.

Data.MeaningHint: You go outside. There's ice everywhere. It's freezing cold. Yep, this is definitely winter.
Data.ReadingHint: Your pronunciation might be a little weird. But that’s okay. People still love your presents, and the way you say "fu’ you!"
Data.ReadingMnemonic: <kanji>Winter</kanji> is also the time of year you give out presents: "One fu' you, one fu' you and… one <reading>fu' you</reading> (ふゆ)!"
Data.MeaningMnemonic: You’ve got a <radical>winter</radical> with lots of <radical>ice</radical>. But doesn't any winter have lots of ice? Exactly. That's why this is just <kanji>winter</kanji>.

Data.MeaningHint: Hold on to that radical knowledge! It'll be the north star that guides you through your studies.
Data.ReadingHint: Yep, those things are called keytars. And for some reason, in the north, everyone has a keytar. They're basically obsessed with them. North = keytar. Quite simple.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: You go north, and notice that everyone has a keytar (きた). You know, those keyboards that people hold and play like a guitar?
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The kanji is the same as the radical — it means <kanji>north</kanji>.

Data.MeaningHint: Imagine the triceratops on its side, then imagine it getting up. When it stands up normally, half of its body is soaking wet still. It's a half-n-half triceratops right now.
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine him using his blaster to shoot the poor triceratops in half, perfectly down the wet-dry line of its body.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: "You're half wet and half dry! I will cut you in <kanji>half</kanji> with my laser blaster so you're proper again," a voice says. It is  <reading>Han</reading> Solo (はん), the anti-establishment guy who hates when things aren't even.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: A <radical>triceratops</radical> is lying out to <radical>dry</radical>. But it's so big, and it's lying on its side, so only <kanji>half</kanji> of it gets dry.

Data.MeaningHint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
Data.ReadingHint:
Imagine a 子 looking at old things. A record player. A Game Boy. A cassette player. Kids just don't get old things.

Note: When you see the (古) radical in a kanji, there's a good chance it will use the reading こ.
Data.ReadingMnemonic:
<kanji>Old</kanji> things are misunderstood by the <reading>子</reading>s (こ) of the world.

*Note:* Come up with a 子 character you can use for all the こ reading mnemonics going forward. This child will show up many times throughout your mnemonic journey, and it will help if you imagine the same character the whole time.
Data.MeaningMnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>old</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>old</kanji> as well.

Note: This "old" does not refer to people. Think of it as "old things" instead.

Data.MeaningHint: Doesn't this kanji look like a machine mouth? Now wouldn't you want to keep that private from the people you know?
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine being so afraid that people will find out about your machine mouth that you have to dye it to match a normal human mouth. Oh, when will this discrimination against machine-kind end?!
Data.ReadingMnemonic: To make sure they can't tell what's <kanji>machine</kanji> and what's human, you <reading>dye</reading> (だい) the mouth to make it look like skin. You find dye the same shade as your normal mouth and just slap it on there.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: You have a <radical>private</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> that's a <kanji>machine</kanji>. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.

Data.MeaningHint: After imagining your <radical>evening</radical> <radical>toe</radical> overheating, rush <kanji>outside</kanji> to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.
Data.ReadingHint: If you don’t know Guy Fawkes, you should do a little reading up on him to make this mnemonic make sense. Also, Anonymous People wear a Guy Fawkes mask, if that helps any.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: You go <kanji>outside</kanji> (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, <reading>Guy</reading> (がい) Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him!
Data.MeaningMnemonic: You're known to get the ailment <radical>evening</radical> <radical>toe</radical>, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go <kanji>outside</kanji>.

Data.MeaningHint: Picture this towel with the name of a city on it. Any city you like. Maybe it's your city!
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine a city that has a sheep everywhere you look, as far as the eye can see. This city was built on sheep, don't you say a bad word about sheep when you're there.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: This <kanji>city</kanji> must have a lot of <reading>shee</reading>p (し) because, besides the manhole lid and the towel, all you can see are sheep. There are sheep everywhere. It's a sheep city.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: You see a manhole <radical>lid</radical> and a <radical>towel</radical>, both with the name of a <kanji>city</kanji> on them. Decorative manhole lids and souvenir towels — two things cities love to slap their names on, especially in Japan.

Data.MeaningHint: You want your private canopy to be wide so you can sprawl out under it as much as you want. No one's going to come in and tell you to close your legs or sit up straight. So it can be as wide as you like!
Data.ReadingHint: Picture yourself lying under your wide, private canopy pretending to be a super hero on the ground. You're stretching a nice, wide super hero pose, like you're flying through the sky.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: You like being <kanji>wide</kanji> because it makes you feel like a different person. But not just any person, like a super <reading>hero</reading> (ひろ)!
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>canopy</radical> you use in <radical>private</radical> is very <kanji>wide</kanji>.

Data.MeaningHint: See how the vertical bar is broken and your window frame is all messed up now? Why would your mother do such a thing?! Her hand is bleeding too…
Data.ReadingHint:
You thought your mother was going to explain or apologize, but instead she's pointing and saying, "Haha," over and over.

Yeah. That sounds like my mom.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Suddenly your <kanji>mother</kanji> points her bloodied finger at you and laughs, "<reading>Haha</reading> (はは)!" She keeps laughing, haha haha haha, over and over. You feel even more alarmed.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: Someone breaks part of your <radical>window</radical>. Who did this? It was your <kanji>mother</kanji>!

Data.MeaningHint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
Data.ReadingHint: Eat your yogurt. (Gogurt doesn't count, don't @ me.)
Data.ReadingMnemonic: Today, your <kanji>task</kanji> is to eat <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). It's nutritious, it's delicious, and I'm telling you to do it, so you have to. A task is basically just something you have to do, so that's what this is.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>task</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>task</kanji> as well.

Data.MeaningHint: Just know your radicals and you'll know this kanji!
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine the arrow as a human-sized living thing with legs, arms, and clothes, though. Strangely, it’s able to walk around even though it's an arrow. It has some kind of agenda. Make it a bit evil, if you can. What a strange thing…
Data.ReadingMnemonic:
To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!).

What is this arrow doing? It’s following around all the <reading>Ya</reading>nkee (や) baseball players, stalking them, waiting to make its move (I’ll let you decide what its “move” is).
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>arrow</radical> radical and the <kanji>arrow</kanji> kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?

Data.MeaningHint: More people can see this character since the kid is on the roof.
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine the child holding up the letter yelling at everyone who passes that the "J" stands for "Jesus." And yes, this kid just loves the Big Lebowski.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: The <kanji>character</kanji> that is being shown is "J," which stands for <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this <kanji>letter</kanji> and <kanji>symbol</kanji>.
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> <radical>child</radical> stands upon the roof, holding up a single <kanji>letter</kanji>, a single <kanji>character</kanji>, a single <kanji>symbol</kanji> for the world to see.

Data.MeaningHint: If you already know the radical, this one's a freebie. That should make your day a little brighter, hm?
Data.ReadingHint: You might also say "Ah!" when you come up with a bright idea, like in those light bulb moments.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: What do you say when you see something <kanji>bright</kanji>? "<reading>Ah</reading> (あ)!" Like when you open the curtain and the sunshine hits your eyes, or someone shines a flashlight right into your face. Ahhhh, so bright!
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>bright</radical> radical and the <kanji>bright</kanji> kanji are the same!

Data.MeaningHint: Study your radicals and you'll read good.
Data.ReadingHint: Imagine having someone's life in the palm of your hands. It's up to you whether you protect it with your saber or... well... do the other thing sabers are for.
Data.ReadingMnemonic: You can save <kanji>life</kanji> or take it away with your new <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). This is the saber you got from doing the correct thing (remember?), and now you need to figure out how to use it with this life. So what do you do?
Data.MeaningMnemonic: The <radical>life</radical> radical and the <kanji>life</kanji> kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
